document_metadata.title: Data Stewardship and Accountability Hypotheses - Rackspace Technology

hypotheses.hypothesis: H7.4-A: Data owners are accountable for data quality outcomes—formal ownership comes with consequence for failures
supporting_evidence_sought: Formal data owners identified with stewardship titles
Owners held accountable when data quality fails (compensation affected, performance reviews negative, remediation mandated)
Owner accountability documented in role descriptions, governance policies
Consequences applied consistently across ownership domains
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Formal ownership absent or fragmented
Data failures occur without owner consequences
Blame lands on executors not owners
Accountability avoided through orphaning or blame externalization

evidence_found.supporting: MINIMAL. CEO reactive interventions Q3-Q4 2024 (walk away policy, sales refresh) could indicate accountability—sales refresh implies sales personnel accountable for pipeline quality. But accountability reactive through crisis not systematic through stewardship.
disconfirming: Deal profitability: Sales formally owns CRM (entry system control), but sales refresh Q3 2024 changed personnel not methodology—accountability landed on individuals not ownership structure, CRM profitability overstatement persists post-refresh indicating accountability insufficient to drive systematic fix (Stage 7.4 blame flow). Delivery absorbs margin erosion cost without formal ownership or entry authority (authority-accountability gap Stage 4.1). Finance not accountable for reporting operationally inaccurate aggregate margins (external reporting audit-accurate Stage 7.3, internal operational inaccuracy tolerated).

Customer identity: NO FORMAL OWNER identified (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains)—customer count discrepancies persist without accountability, no function held responsible for reconciliation absence, orphaned domain means no owner to hold accountable.

Support ticketing: Support owns ticketing system but NOT accountable for completeness—executive escalations unrecorded (Stage 7.3 support ticketing tolerance), support metrics preserved despite data incompleteness, support not held accountable for escalation necessity or recording gaps.

Satisfaction measurement: NO FORMAL OWNER (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains), satisfaction deterioration ('consistently worse' Trustpilot 2024) occurs without accountability, no function blamed or held responsible for measurement gap or decline, orphaned domain creates accountability void.

Incident frequency: Operations owns response but NOT accountable for prevention—incident recurrence (ransomware multi-month, zero-day Sept 2024) occurs without prevention accountability, operations praised for response capability not blamed for recurrence (Stage 7.4 blame flow blame externalization), prevention orphaned (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains).

Multi-jurisdictional aggregation: Finance owns aggregation methodology but NOT accountable for operational accuracy—variance erasure creates execution failures (Stage 7.3 aggregation tolerance operations absorbs misallocation), operations blamed for execution not finance for methodology, finance insulated from operational consequences of aggregation choices.

hypotheses.notes: Hypothesis decisively refuted. Formal data ownership does NOT come with outcome accountability—ownership fragmented, orphaned, or decoupled from consequences. Pattern: Functions control data systems (sales CRM, support ticketing, finance aggregation, operations incident data) but not accountable for outcome failures (profitability erosion, satisfaction decline, escalation necessity, recurrence, execution failures from aggregation). Accountability lands DOWNSTREAM on executors not UPSTREAM on owners: Delivery blamed for margin erosion (sales CRM entry caused), operations blamed for execution failures (finance aggregation caused), CEO absorbs escalations (support ticketing incompleteness caused). Orphaned domains have NO OWNER to hold accountable (customer identity, satisfaction, incident prevention, profitability validation gap, escalation process)—accountability void by design. When accountability applied, targets INDIVIDUALS not SYSTEMS (sales refresh personnel changes, not CRM methodology reform)—individual blame allows structural causes to persist. Refutation indicates: Accountability systematically misaligned with authority (Stage 4.1 authority-accountability gaps pervasive)—those with authority over data systems (sales CRM entry, finance aggregation) insulated from outcome consequences, those without authority (delivery execution, operations absorbing misallocation) blamed for outcomes. Stewardship titles absent for material domains (no Chief Data Officer, no customer data steward, no prevention steward, no escalation owner, no satisfaction owner Stage 7.4 orphaned domains analysis)—without formal stewardship, accountability defaults to crisis-driven blame landing on visible failure points (execution) not root causes (ownership, methodology, governance).

hypotheses.hypothesis: H7.4-B: Accountability follows authority—functions with control over data systems bear responsibility for data quality
supporting_evidence_sought: Sales accountable for CRM accuracy (controls CRM entry)
Finance accountable for aggregation accuracy (controls methodology)
Support accountable for ticketing completeness (controls system)
Operations accountable for incident data quality (controls recording)
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Authority over systems without downstream accountability
Blame lands on executors without system control
System controllers insulated when controlled data fails
Authority-accountability gaps systematic

evidence_found.supporting: Sales refresh Q3 2024 could indicate sales accountability for CRM (sales personnel changed suggesting pipeline quality accountability). But refresh changed individuals not sales as function—individuals blamed, sales CRM methodology control retained without accountability for methodology quality.
disconfirming: Sales controls CRM entry but delivery blamed for profitability consequences—sales authority over opportunity qualification and valuation (Stage 7.2 transformation T1 sales controlled), but margin erosion absorbed by delivery (execution losses from unprofitable deals), CEO filters deals reactively (walk away policy Q4 2024), sales methodology unchanged post-refresh indicating accountability gap (authority retained, consequences externalized Stage 7.4 blame flow deal profitability).

Finance controls aggregation methodology but operations blamed for execution failures—finance authority over how jurisdiction metrics combined (Stage 7.2 transformation finance controls aggregation), but operations absorbs misallocation from variance erasure (investment in wrong jurisdiction, capacity constraints invisible in aggregates), operations blamed for 'execution gaps' caused by finance methodology (Stage 7.4 blame flow aggregation finance not blamed operations blamed).

Support controls ticketing system but CEO absorbs escalation workload—support authority over ticket recording, resolution status, SLA calculation, but CEO handles escalations support should resolve (manual resolution outside system Stage 7.3), support metrics preserved (SLA compliance high) while CEO bandwidth consumed, support not accountable for escalation prevention or recording (Stage 7.4 blame flow support not blamed CEO absorbs).

Operations controls incident classification but blame externalized—operations authority over incident severity assignment, MTTD/MTTR measurement, root cause documentation (Stage 7.2 authority controls transformation Pattern 4), but incident recurrence blamed on external threats/vendors/resources not operations prevention gaps (blame externalization Stage 7.4), operations praised for response capability without prevention accountability despite classification control.

Delivery lacks CRM entry authority but absorbs profitability accountability—delivery discovers deal unprofitability post-signature (no authority to reject deals pre-signature, no control over CRM qualification criteria), but delivery blamed for 'execution cost overruns' or 'delivery inefficiency' when deals unprofitable from contract terms (authority-accountability inversion: accountability without authority Stage 4.1).

hypotheses.notes: Hypothesis comprehensively refuted. Accountability does NOT follow authority—systematic authority-accountability misalignment pervasive (Stage 4.1 authority-accountability gaps confirmed in data stewardship context). Pattern: Functions with AUTHORITY over data systems (sales CRM, finance aggregation, support ticketing, operations classification) INSULATED from consequences when data fails. Functions with EXECUTION RESPONSIBILITY but without SYSTEM CONTROL blamed for failures caused upstream (delivery blamed for profitability despite no CRM authority, operations blamed for execution despite aggregation methodology not controlled). Authority-accountability INVERSION: Accountability lands where failures visible (execution, customer impact) not where decisions made (system entry, methodology design, qualification criteria). Functions optimize systems for LOCAL BENEFIT without DOWNSTREAM ACCOUNTABILITY (sales CRM optimism benefits sales compensation Stage 4.4, finance aggregation simplicity benefits investor communications, support ticketing incompleteness preserves SLA metrics, operations incident classification preserves response narrative)—optimization creates externalities (margin erosion, execution failures, escalation workload, recurrence) absorbed by others without authority to prevent. CEO absorbs multiple accountabilities without system authority (CEO filters deals lacking CRM qualification authority, CEO handles escalations lacking ticketing system control, CEO arbitrates disputes lacking data governance authority Stage 7.1)—CEO reactive accountability accumulation indicates systematic accountability-authority misalignment across organization. Refutation indicates: Blame flows to EXECUTION not METHODOLOGY, to OUTCOMES not INPUTS, to VISIBLE FAILURES not ROOT CAUSES—structural bias toward blaming executors (delivery, operations execution) not designers (sales entry, finance methodology), bias enabled by authority-accountability gaps allowing system controllers to externalize consequences while retaining control.

hypotheses.hypothesis: H7.4-C: Escalation leads to resolution—when data issues escalated to CEO/executives, systematic fixes implemented preventing recurrence
supporting_evidence_sought: CEO interventions (walk away policy, sales refresh) followed by systematic quality improvement
Escalated issues result in governance infrastructure building (committees, processes, accountability assignment)
Root causes addressed not just symptoms treated
Post-escalation, similar issues don't recur
disconfirming_evidence_sought: CEO interventions treat symptoms not causes
Escalation results in individual blame (personnel changes) not systematic fixes (methodology reform)
Governance infrastructure not built post-escalation
Issues recur after CEO intervention indicating incomplete resolution

evidence_found.supporting: Walk away policy Q4 2024 and sales refresh Q3 2024 demonstrate CEO escalation resulted in action—CEO intervened when margin erosion and pipeline quality deteriorated, established filtering policy, changed personnel. Evidence of CEO responsive to escalated issues when severe enough to capture bandwidth.
disconfirming: Walk away policy TREATS SYMPTOMS not causes—policy filters unprofitable deals reactively (CEO reviews deals sales already signed), but doesn't reform CRM qualification methodology at entry (Stage 7.4 blame flow deal profitability authority fix authority sales retains CRM control, methodology unchanged), structural cause persists (sales can continue entering optimistic opportunities, CEO filtering becomes permanent necessity not temporary intervention), policy non-transferable if CEO transitions (three CEOs three years, walk away policy may not survive CEO change Stage 4.5).

Sales refresh TREATS SYMPTOMS not causes—refresh changes sales personnel (individuals blamed for pipeline quality), but doesn't systematize pipeline validation or change CRM qualification standards (Stage 7.4 blame flow sales refresh methodology unchanged, Stage 7.4 orphaned domains profitability validation gap persists), new personnel may repeat pattern (incentive structure unchanged Stage 4.4 bookings-based compensation, CRM entry methodology unchanged, individuals changed but systemic enablers remain).

NO GOVERNANCE INFRASTRUCTURE BUILT post-interventions—walk away policy and sales refresh Q3-Q4 2024 didn't establish: operating committee for cross-functional coordination (Stage 4.1 coordination infrastructure remains absent), deal review board for systematic profitability validation (Stage 7.1 H7.1-B governance void persists), data governance committee for quality oversight (governance committees not created), accountability documentation (RACI matrices, stewardship assignments not produced). Interventions episodic CEO personal actions not institutionalized governance.

Customer escalations to CEO—BBB complaints, direct CEO contact for issue resolution (Stage 7.3 support ticketing tolerance, Stage 7.4 orphaned domains escalation process), CEO resolves individual customer issues manually, but escalation path not systematized (escalation process remains informal, ticketing system completeness not mandated, support accountability for escalation prevention not assigned), escalation pattern continues (customers still require BBB/CEO escalation to achieve resolution, systematic fix absent).

Incident recurrence continues—ransomware multi-month indicates incident escalation didn't prevent recurrence (operations responded, root cause analyzed, but prevention not implemented or insufficient), zero-day Sept 2024 exploitation indicates vulnerability management gaps persist despite incident history (previous incidents didn't drive systematic prevention infrastructure building, recurrence pattern tolerated Stage 7.4 orphaned domains prevention orphaned).

hypotheses.notes: Hypothesis weakened significantly—escalation produces CEO action but not systematic resolution. CEO interventions REACTIVE SYMPTOM TREATMENT not PROACTIVE CAUSE ELIMINATION: Walk away policy filters bad deals but doesn't prevent bad deal entry (CRM methodology unchanged), sales refresh changes people but doesn't fix pipeline validation absence (systematic quality assurance not built), customer escalation resolution doesn't systematize escalation path (ticketing completeness not mandated), incident escalation doesn't build prevention infrastructure (recurrence continues). CEO interventions EPISODIC not INSTITUTIONAL: Interventions personal CEO actions (walk away policy CEO discretion, sales refresh CEO judgment, customer escalations CEO manual resolution) not governance processes (no deal review board replacing CEO filtering, no escalation committee replacing CEO resolution, no incident prevention steward replacing ad-hoc responses)—if CEO transitions, interventions may not transfer (three CEOs three years suggests non-transferability risk Stage 4.5). Escalation TO CEO indicates GOVERNANCE VOID (Stage 7.1 H7.1-B)—systematic governance would resolve issues at lower organizational levels (operating committee for profitability disputes, data governance committee for quality issues, customer experience committee for escalations), escalation to CEO required because systematic resolution mechanisms absent, CEO becomes organizational SPOF for data issue resolution (Stage 4.2 CEO bottleneck worsened by escalation burden). Post-escalation RECURRENCE indicates incomplete resolution: CRM profitability issues likely continue (methodology unchanged, new personnel may repeat optimism), customer escalations continue (systematic path not built), incident recurrence continues (prevention orphaned)—symptoms treated creating temporary relief, causes remain creating recurrence. Hypothesis NOT FULLY REFUTED because escalation does produce action (walk away policy established, sales refresh executed, customer issues resolved)—but action INSUFFICIENT for systematic resolution (symptoms treated not causes fixed, episodic not institutional, recurrence likely). Escalation serves as PRESSURE RELEASE not SYSTEMATIC FIX—CEO intervention addresses immediate crisis (margin erosion stopped by deal filtering, immediate customer issue resolved), reduces escalation pressure temporarily, but structural issues enabling crisis persist (governance void, authority-accountability gaps, incentive misalignments) allowing recurrence.

hypotheses.hypothesis: H7.4-D: Blame drives quality improvement—when functions blamed for data failures, they implement fixes preventing recurrence
supporting_evidence_sought: Sales refresh Q3 2024 improved pipeline quality (personnel change followed by methodology reform)
Blamed functions implement systematic quality improvements
Quality metrics improve post-blame
Recurrence rates decline after function held accountable
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Blame lands on individuals not systems (personnel changes without methodology reform)
Blamed functions change people not processes
Quality doesn't improve post-blame or improvement temporary
Blame redirected/externalized rather than accepted

evidence_found.supporting: Sales refresh Q3 2024 could indicate blame-driven improvement—sales personnel changes imply sales blamed for pipeline quality, refresh intended to improve quality. Walk away policy Q4 2024 implies sales CRM optimism blamed (policy necessary to filter sales-entered deals), policy may improve accuracy if sales anticipates CEO filtering.
disconfirming: Sales refresh changed PERSONNEL not METHODOLOGY—individuals blamed and replaced (sales team members or leadership changed Q3 2024), but CRM qualification criteria, profitability validation requirements, incentive structure unchanged (Stage 7.4 blame flow sales refresh methodology unchanged, Stage 4.4 sales incentive bookings-based persists). Personnel change addresses individual judgment/performance, doesn't address systematic optimism enabled by: (1) bookings-based compensation (incentive to maximize volume Stage 4.4), (2) CRM qualification methodology absence (no validation required Stage 7.4 orphaned domains profitability validation gap), (3) authority-accountability misalignment (sales enters, delivery absorbs Stage 4.1). New personnel operating in same system likely repeat pattern.

Walk away policy REACTIVE FILTERING not PROACTIVE PREVENTION—policy doesn't prevent CRM optimism at entry (sales can still enter optimistic opportunities), policy filters deals post-entry when CEO reviews (reactive not proactive), sales effort wasted on deals CEO later rejects (wasted sales cycle), policy treats symptoms (filters output) not causes (fixes input methodology). If policy intended to drive sales entry behavior change (sales self-filters anticipating CEO rejection), effectiveness depends on: (1) Policy transparency (criteria documented—but Stage 7.1 uncertainty walk away criteria undocumented, CEO case-by-case judgment), (2) sales ability to predict CEO decisions (unpredictable without documented criteria), (3) sales incentive to self-filter (conflicts with bookings volume incentive Stage 4.4). Without transparency/incentive alignment, policy reactive filter not sales behavior modification.

Support NOT BLAMED for ticketing incompleteness—executive escalations unrecorded (Stage 7.3 support ticketing tolerance), but support not held accountable (blame avoided Stage 7.4 blame flow support not blamed), SLA metrics preserved despite data gaps, support no incentive to fix (fixing degrades metrics Stage 7.3 touch test), incompleteness persists. Blame absence = improvement absence.

Operations NOT BLAMED for incident prevention—recurrence externalized to threats/vendors/resources not operations gaps (blame externalization Stage 7.4 blame flow), operations praised for response capability, prevention orphaned (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains), blame avoidance allows prevention deprioritization, recurrence continues (ransomware multi-month, zero-day Sept 2024). Blame absence = improvement absence.

Finance NOT BLAMED for aggregation methodology—operations blamed for execution failures caused by variance erasure (Stage 7.4 blame flow), finance insulated, aggregation methodology unchanged, misallocation continues, finance no pressure to disaggregate or caveat. Blame absence = improvement absence.

hypotheses.notes: Hypothesis refuted. Blame does NOT consistently drive quality improvement—blame produces personnel changes or symptom treatment without systematic fixes. Sales refresh ILLUSTRATES PATTERN: Blame lands on individuals (sales personnel accountable for pipeline quality), individuals changed, but systems unchanged (CRM methodology, incentive structure, validation requirements all persist Stage 7.4 blame flow)—individual blame allows organizational systems to avoid scrutiny, individuals scapegoated while structural enablers remain. Walk away policy SYMPTOM TREATMENT not CAUSE PREVENTION: Policy filters bad deals after entry (treats symptoms of CRM optimism), doesn't reform entry methodology preventing optimism (leaves cause unaddressed), reactive filtering becomes ongoing necessity (CEO permanently involved in deal review consuming bandwidth Stage 4.2), systematic fix (profitability validation at entry, CRM methodology reform, incentive realignment) not implemented. Blame ABSENCE prevents improvement in multiple domains: Support not blamed for ticketing incompleteness → incompleteness persists. Operations not blamed for prevention → recurrence continues. Finance not blamed for aggregation methodology → misallocation continues. Customer identity not blamed (orphaned domain) → discrepancies persist. Satisfaction not blamed (orphaned domain) → deterioration continues. Pattern: Blame necessary but INSUFFICIENT for improvement—blame must land on SYSTEMS not INDIVIDUALS, must be ACCEPTED not EXTERNALIZED, must drive METHODOLOGY REFORM not PERSONNEL ROTATION. Blame landing on individuals (sales personnel) allows systems to persist. Blame externalization (incident recurrence blamed on threats not prevention) allows gaps to persist. Blame avoidance (support, finance insulation) removes pressure for improvement. Refutation indicates: Current blame patterns COUNTERPRODUCTIVE for quality improvement—blame focuses on execution (individuals, visible failures) not methodology (systems, root causes), produces scapegoating (individual turnover) not learning (process improvement), enables blame avoidance by system owners (sales methodology, finance aggregation, support ticketing unchanged despite failures). Quality improvement requires: Blame on METHODOLOGY not PEOPLE (CRM qualification process reformed not sales personnel replaced), blame ACCEPTANCE not EXTERNALIZATION (operations owns prevention not externalizes to threats), blame ASSIGNMENT in orphaned domains (customer identity steward blamed for reconciliation absence, satisfaction owner blamed for measurement gap)—current blame patterns avoid methodology/system accountability enabling persistence.

hypotheses.hypothesis: H7.4-E: Formal data stewardship roles exist and function—Chief Data Officer or equivalent coordinates enterprise data accountability
supporting_evidence_sought: Chief Data Officer role identified
Data stewardship roles assigned by domain (customer data steward, financial data steward, operational data steward)
Data governance committee with stewards as members
Stewards have documented authority and accountability for data quality
disconfirming_evidence_sought: No Chief Data Officer or equivalent role exists
Data stewardship titles absent
Stewardship fragmented across functions without coordination
Stewardship orphaned for material domains

evidence_found.supporting: NONE. No formal data stewardship roles identified across Stage 4, 7.1, 7.2, 7.3, 7.4 analysis.
disconfirming: NO CHIEF DATA OFFICER identified—no executive role consolidating enterprise data accountability across domains (customer data, financial data, operational data, compliance data). No equivalent role (VP Data Governance, Director of Data Quality, Chief Analytics Officer with data stewardship mandate) identified in evidence reviewed.

NO DATA STEWARDSHIP TITLES for material domains—Customer identity stewardship: ABSENT (orphaned Stage 7.4, no customer data steward). Deal profitability data stewardship: ABSENT (orphaned between sales-delivery Stage 7.4). Satisfaction measurement stewardship: ABSENT (orphaned Stage 7.4, no customer experience data owner). Incident prevention data stewardship: ABSENT (orphaned Stage 7.4, response owned but prevention not). Support escalation data stewardship: ABSENT (orphaned Stage 7.4, ticketing system owned but escalation process not). Aggregation methodology stewardship: Finance controls but not accountable for operational accuracy (Stage 7.4 blame flow, stewardship title not identified).

NO DATA GOVERNANCE COMMITTEE—Stage 7.1 H7.1-B governance void confirmed across analysis, no data governance committee establishing enterprise standards, assigning stewards, resolving data disputes, mandating quality requirements. Governance infrastructure absence means stewardship roles couldn't function even if created (no forum for steward coordination, no mandate for steward authority, no escalation path for steward disputes).

STEWARDSHIP FRAGMENTED across functions without coordination—sales owns CRM (customer data fragment), finance owns billing (customer data fragment), support owns engagement (customer data fragment), but no steward consolidating fragments into enterprise customer truth (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains customer identity). Operations owns incident response data, security owns vulnerability data, vendors create incident risk data (Stage 6), but no steward consolidating into incident prevention accountability (Stage 7.4 orphaned domains prevention). Fragmentation without consolidation = stewardship absence.

Three CEOs three years, NONE built data stewardship infrastructure—consistent absence across CEO tenures suggests systemic deprioritization not individual CEO oversight (Stage 4.5 talent constraints, CEO bandwidth consumed by operational firefighting Stage 4.2 preventing governance building). If data stewardship prioritized, at least one CEO would have created CDO or equivalent—absence indicates low organizational priority for formal data accountability.

hypotheses.notes: Hypothesis decisively refuted. Formal data stewardship roles ABSENT not present. No Chief Data Officer, no domain-specific stewards, no data governance committee, no stewardship infrastructure. Data accountability defaults to: (1) System control (functions owning systems implicitly 'own' data—sales CRM, finance billing, support ticketing, operations incidents), but system control without stewardship mandate = accountability gaps (control without outcome responsibility). (2) Crisis-driven CEO intervention (CEO becomes de facto steward through reactive arbitration—walk away policy, sales refresh, customer escalations, cross-functional disputes Stage 7.4 blame flow), but CEO stewardship episodic not systematic (bandwidth limits prevent proactive governance Stage 4.2). (3) Orphaning (domains requiring cross-functional coordination or politically expensive—customer identity, satisfaction, prevention, profitability validation, escalation process—remain unowned Stage 7.4 orphaned domains). Stewardship absence STRUCTURALLY ENABLED by governance void (Stage 7.1 H7.1-B)—without data governance committee, no forum to create steward roles, assign stewards, empower stewards with authority. CEO bottleneck (Stage 4.2) prevents stewardship building—CEO bandwidth consumed by operational firefighting, lacks capacity for governance infrastructure design (steward role definition, accountability assignment, steward empowerment). Three CEOs three years (Stage 4.5) prevents institutional stewardship—if CEO attempted stewardship building, CEO transition before institutionalization, next CEO prioritizes differently or repeats cycle. Capital constraints ($1.3B debt Stage 5) may limit steward headcount—CDO/steward roles require executive compensation, but stewardship coordination work (committees, policies, RACI matrices) primarily requires leadership bandwidth not capital, bandwidth constraint more binding than capital. Refutation indicates: Data accountability BY DEFAULT not BY DESIGN—functions control systems without explicit stewardship mandate, CEO intervenes reactively without systematic governance, domains requiring coordination orphaned without steward assignment. Stewardship void creates: Accountability gaps (control without outcome responsibility), orphaned domains (cross-functional coordination requirements without coordinators), blame diffusion (no clear steward to hold accountable when domain fails), M&A integration complexity (acquirer finds no data owners to engage for integration, must build stewardship post-close or absorb fragmented accountability).

synthesis_notes: All hypotheses testing systematic data accountability REFUTED or WEAKENED. H7.4-A REFUTED: Formal ownership doesn't create outcome accountability (owners insulated, blame lands downstream on executors). H7.4-B REFUTED: Accountability doesn't follow authority (systematic authority-accountability inversion, system controllers avoid consequences). H7.4-C WEAKENED: Escalation produces CEO action but not systematic resolution (symptoms treated not causes fixed, episodic not institutional, recurrence likely). H7.4-D REFUTED: Blame doesn't drive improvement (individual scapegoating not methodology reform, blame avoidance in multiple domains removes improvement pressure). H7.4-E REFUTED: Formal stewardship roles absent (no CDO, no domain stewards, no governance committee, stewardship by default not design). Refutations interconnected through structural root causes: Governance void (Stage 7.1 H7.1-B) prevents stewardship role creation, accountability documentation, systematic dispute resolution. Authority-accountability gaps (Stage 4.1) enable system controllers to externalize consequences while retaining control (sales CRM authority but delivery absorbs margins, finance aggregation authority but operations absorbs misallocation). CEO bottleneck (Stage 4.2) forces reactive episodic intervention not proactive systematic governance, bandwidth consumed by firefighting prevents stewardship building. Three CEOs three years (Stage 4.5) prevents accountability institutionalization, each CEO rediscovers issues through crises, interventions non-transferable across transitions. Incentive misalignments (Stage 4.4) create improvement resistance—blame-driven quality improvement requires methodology reform conflicting with function incentives (sales CRM tightening conflicts with bookings volume incentive, support escalation recording conflicts with SLA optimization, operations prevention investment conflicts with response capability focus). Accountability pattern: BLAME FLOWS DOWNSTREAM to execution (delivery, operations execution), UPSTREAM system controllers INSULATED (sales methodology, finance aggregation, support ticketing, operations classification), ORPHANED DOMAINS have NO OWNER to blame (customer identity, satisfaction, prevention, profitability validation, escalation process), CEO ABSORBS residual accountability (filters deals, resolves escalations, arbitrates disputes) without authority to prevent upstream (CRM methodology control, ticketing system control, aggregation methodology control remain with functions). M&A implications: Acquirer discovers accountability void (no stewards to engage), orphaned domains requiring ownership assignment, blame patterns enabling persistent quality issues, CEO-dependent episodic management non-transferable to acquirer context (acquirer CEO lacks Rackspace operational detail bandwidth), integration requires accountability consolidation or acquirer inherits fragmented reactive pattern.
